awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The common attentional and dynamical properties of decision making
awd_abstract_narration:
Over the last decade there has been much interest in how people make decisions, fueled in large part by data from novel neuroscience techniques.  However, these advancements in data collection have not yet been matched by advancements in our understanding of the cognitive processes that guide decision-making.  This project seeks to bridge that gap by generating mathematical models of the underlying choice processes that can then be tested using a variety of data, such as eye movements during the evaluation of the options, hand movements during the execution of the choice, and the overall time that it takes to make a decision.  Unlike prior research in decision-making, this project aims to develop models that can be applied and tested across different types of choices.  This will yield unique insights into the principles that guide all choices, as well as potentially identify what makes some types of choices unique.  The research will also investigate how individual differences in attention, preference, and learning strategies, as well as environmental factors such as time pressure, influence the choice process.  This work will advance our basic understanding of the mind and help us to quantitatively predict the effects of new institutions, policies, and behavioral interventions.  The educational and outreach projects will expose people of all ages to the exciting work being done in decision science and will ensure continuing public interest and pursuit of careers in STEM, through research internships, summer institutes, workshops, and courses aimed at increasing student interest in this work, as well as televised programs featuring prominent decision neuroscientists, and public lectures from the PI, intended to reach a broader segment of the public. 
 
This project is an integrated research, education, and outreach program focused on dynamical modeling of the interactions between attention and choice in human decision making.  The program features an innovative computational approach to studying the features that are common (and unique) to different types of decisions, creating links between previously disjoint domains, and shedding new light onto the general principles underlying human behavior.  The overall objectives of this project are to study the attention-guided comparison process in single and multi-dimensional choice problems and differences in this process between individuals; to determine what processes guide learning and how they differ across individuals; to investigate how these processes change in social settings and whether people learn from others? choice processes; and to develop and test models of how people assign value to objects in their environment.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project has advanced our understanding of human decision making. Prior decision research has either focused on mathematical models of choice outcomes or heuristic models of choice processes. In this project, we bridged the gap by developing mathematical models of choice processes. These models treat the choice process as a gaze-driven accumulation and comparison of evidence for each of the alternatives (and their attributes). With these 'sequential sampling models', we were able to identify consistent relationships between gaze, response times, and choice outcomes, across choices in different domains, choices with many alternatives, and choices with multiple attributes. We established that gaze amplifies value, leading to larger gaze-induced choice biases and faster decisions between high-value alternatives. These gaze effects correlate with individual differences in 'tunnel vision' but are stronger in decisions made purely from memory. Importantly, these gaze effects are causal; attention manipulations lead to corresponding choice biases. In other work, we demonstrated that it is possible to learn more about people's preferences and beliefs by considering choice-process data such as response times and hand movements. Moreover, we showed that people pay attention to others' choice processes and infer stronger preferences/beliefs from faster responses. In the learning domain, we developed a model of epiphany learning and showed that gaze data could be used to predict the likelihood and onset of epiphanies. We also used eye- and hand-movements to reveal that people often possess but fail to properly use knowledge of their environment to plan good decisions, instead using error-prone, on-the-spot evaluations. Finally, we used our modeling framework to show how choices can be decomposed into predispositions and evaluations, and thus argued that contrary to norms in the literature, preferences cannot be equated with choices. The project resulted in 27 peer reviewed publications and numerous seminars and presentations.

 

Broader Impacts

This project has had a substantial impact on education and outreach activities. It resulted in six completed Ph.D. dissertations, with four more in progress. In total, 13 graduate students and 25 undergraduates participated in research related to the project. The project also led to a new undergraduate/graduate level course, cross-listed between Economics and Psychology, on 'Neuroeconomics and Decision Neuroscience.'  This course now enlists 100 students each time it is taught. The project also supported a partnership with the Ohio Supercomputing Center to run five annual two-week summer institutes for talented high-school students. As a result of the project, the PI also gave two presentations at the Columbus Center of Science and Industry (COSI) and partnered with the WOSU Public Media to organize a public roundtable on 'The Neuroscience of Self Control' featuring three well-known social/decision neuroscientists.  Finally, the PI organized three pre-conference workshops on 'choice-process data' at the annual Economic Science Association meeting. The workshop has attracted roughly 80 attendees each year. In 2019 it led to a special issue of the society's journal (JESA) dedicated to the topic; the PI was a guest editor of that special issue. In sum, the project has had substantial impact at many levels, including graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students, academics in multiple disciplines, and the general public.
